Award.AwardTitle: Conference--Evolution at 150: Looking to the Future: a 2009 celebration of the 150th anniversary of The Origin of Species
Award.AbstractNarration: A Darwin 2009 Celebration Meeting will be held at the American Museum of Natural History and Stony Brook University over a 5-day period to honor the 150th anniversary of the publication of Charles Darwin?s Origin of Species. The meeting will combine public outreach and teacher workshop activities at the Museum with formal presentations and informal discussions at the University. The goals of the meeting are to analyze history of ideas in evolutionary biology, discuss contemporary fields of inquiry and future research directions, analyze the impact of evolutionary thinking for disciplines outside biology, such as philosophy, sociology and humanities, and promote translation of science to the general public and media through education and outreach. The meeting is designed to provide opportunities for intellectual discourse and development of evolutionary biology in a broad sense with potential impact on research agendas and funding priorities for the near future. The meeting also will include significant outreach components targeted at science teachers and the general public with the goal of increasing understanding of science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
2009 marked the 150th anniversary of the publication of Charles R. Darwin’s On the Origin of Species, which revolutionized how we view biological diversity and the human place in nature. The National Science Foundation supported two workshops in November 2009 to mark this anniversary, a workshop for professionals at Stony Brook University and an outreach workshop at the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH) aimed primarily at secondary school teachers.

“Darwin 2009” was a workshop for active researchers in evolutionary biology at Stony Brook University held from November 4 to 7, 2009. It brought together 22 speakers, 12 discussants and about 80 observers from Stony Brook University. A volume of chapters based on presentations by the 22 speakers at this workshop entitled, Evolution Since Darwin; the First 150 Years, was edited by M. A. Bell, D. J. Futuyma, W. F. Eanes, and J. S. Levinton and published by Sinauer Associates in 2010. It reviewed the history, current status, and expectations for future developments in several major areas of evolutionary biology.

“Darwin’s Legacy: the Impact of Evolution on Everyday Life” was an outreach workshop led by active researchers in evolutionary biology and held at the American Museum of Natural History in New York City. It included six public lectures and guided and unguided tours of the exhibition halls at the AMNH. The audience included 113 secondary science teachers, 25 AMNH staff members, and 16 AMNH teaching volunteers. Participants received a DVD of all print media from the workshop, a CD with classroom activities, other AMNH publications on electronic media, and a volume entitled, Science, Evolution and Creationism, published by the National Academy of Sciences and Institute of Medicine.

Informal feedback from participants in “Darwin 2009” was very positive, and we believe that the volume based on this workshop provides a valuable record of the state of evolutionary biology on the 150th anniversary of the birth of the field. Formal evaluations from 113 teachers who participated in “Darwin’s Legacy: the Impact of Evolution on Everyday Life” averaged between 4.0 and 4.6, on a scale 1 to 5.
